column1: Sanskrit Vocab from Maurer and Goldmans

column5:
"from this" (sing, dual or plur), spatially,from here, (i.e., from this place), hence; 
temporarily, then, from that time; causally, therefore.
prefix used with adjectives and adverbs to mean 'very,' 'too,' 'excessively'

"in this" (sing., dual, or plural), spatially, in this place, here; 
temporally, then; referentially, with regard to this or that point, in this or that case.
moreover, however, even so (equals atha in most cases)
below; as a postp. with the gen., under; beneath

go up to, arrive at, go to, go unto, approach; attain, obtain; 
ppp: adhigata; gerund: adhigamya or adhigatya

immediately after, afterwards, thereupon; then (like tataḥ); 
[used as postp. at end of a cpd]
remorse; regret [literally 'a burning or suffering after']
a going after, following; conformity, accordance; if in instrumental (anusareṇa) with genitive as quasi-postposed, then 'in accordance with,' or literally 'due to the following of'
many [literally, 'not one,' i.e., more than one]
in many ways [dhā = an adverb forming suffix indicating manner]
other [declined like the demonstrative pronouns, i.e., saḥ, tat, sā]
having gone away, past passive participle of apa-√gam (apagacchati)
other, another (declined like para - see chapter 5 of Goldmans)

also, even; often concessivly after an adj or part., though; apyuta= also;
if at beginning of a sentence indicates yes/no question
overcome; past passive participle of abhi-√bhū (abhibhavati)
addressed, accosted; past passive participle of abhi-√bhaṣ (abhibhāṣate)
be fit, worthy, be worthy to, deserve, have a right to, be obliged to, have to, should, must (+ infinitive), be pleased to (+ infinitive); be able, can
see, look at; ppp: avalokita [technically a causative without causative meaning]
stand off (ava)', stand, stand up, ppp: avasthita; infinitive: avasthātum

causative of ava-√sthā (avatiṣṭhti), literally 'stand off or apart', 
hence as causative, 'causes (someone) to stand off or apart,' leave behind
commands; causative of आ-√ज्ञा (आजानाति) ā-√jñā (ājānāti) to understand, perceive, a class 9 verb
self, Self, commonly used as reflexive
noble person, lord; as term of address = sir
"my lord"; used by wife to husband
having reflected; gerund of आ+√लोच् (आलोचयति ) ā+√loc (ālocayati)
so, thus; marks the end of a thought or quoted speech
like, as (follows word to which it refers)
said, spoken, spoken to, addressed; past passive participle of √vac (vakti)
having said or spoken; gerund of √vac (vacati) a class 2 verb, to say or speak
stand up; although it's ud-√thā, the underlying is ud + √sthā
literally, 'cause to go forth, produce;' gerund: utpādya
having stayed, having abided; gerund of √vas (vasati) to dwell
one [declined like the demonstrative pronouns, i.e., saḥ, tat, sā]
from one side, on the one hand
at one time or one day, at a certain time, once, one time, once upon a time
who, what, which - can be used on its own (who is it?) or with a noun (which man is he?)
a small seashell used as a coin in barter
"a certain," a/an, also could have double meaning of "an extraordinary" per Hareesh
do, make, conduct; infinitive: kartum (3rd p plural, kurvanti)
done, made; past passive participle of √kṛ (karoti)
the tip or end of the hair or mane (a compound made up of kesara (m) hair, mane + agra (n) the tip  or  end
destruction; acc + √kṛ 'make a destruction of,' bring an end, exhaust
agitated, shaken; to reduce confusion, following Goldmans who list it in adjectives; past passive participle of √kṣubh (kṣobhate),  shake
having gone, gone, past passive participle of √गम् (गच्छति ) √gam (gacchati )
heavy; (f version = gurvī) as a masculine noun: teacher
and (placed after a series or between each pair of a series)
four; irregular declension - f. acc. plural = catusraḥ
a foursome, a set of four (goldmans cite in the nominative and don't give the stem - since we mostly follow Maurer, I took the m off to avoid confusion)
turns the interrogative pronoun into an indefinite (i.e., kaś (who) + cana = someone
turns the interrogative pronoun into an indefinite (i.e., kiṃ (what) + cit = something
of a long time, long-standing [cira, 'long'+ kāla 'time' + īna, 'pertaining to']
smash, break to pieces (literally 'reduce to powder); a denominative verb from cūrṇ, 'powder' (see Lesson 28)
(having been) smashed; past passive participle of √cūrṇaya (cūrṇayati)
cut; nibbled; past passive participle of √छिद् (छिनत्ति ) √chid (chinatti)
person; as collective noun, people; plural, folk
name of Sītā's father, king of Mithilā
waste away, age; also a class 4 P verb
there, with regard to that, concerning that
in that way, thus, so; "So be it!"; a common way of indicating aquiescence in what another says
blade of grass, a straw; often used metaphorically for something of little consequence or value
having abandoned, having left aside, gerund of √tyaj (tyajati)
abandons, gives up, leave aside; ppp: tyakta; gerund tyaktvā
the act of seeing, seeing, looking at, view
to give; with śraddhaṃ, 'to perform a śraddha'; infinitive of √dā (dadāti)
having been seen; past passive participle of √dṛś, to see, which is irregular and is not used in the present; see √paś, to see, for present tense
having seen; gerund of √dṛś, to see, which is irregular and is not used in the present; see √paś, to see, for present tense
one of the most common scripts in which Sanskrit is written
a thing (in the most general sense), article
two; actual stem is dva but is treated as an "a" stem noun only in the dual

(m) usually used to indicate the priestly caste of the Brāhmaṇas; literally,'twice-born,' a term applied to a member of the upper three classes of Hindu society, because when they receive the sacred thread, they are said to go through a second birth. Also, any animal born of an egg is also called dvija, twice-born.
law, duty, right, "etc"; Hareesh has advised using Dharma instead of trying to imperfectly translate
hold, keep, retain; Maurer comments that it's a causative without causative meaning
held, retained, kept; past passive participle of √धृ (धारयति √dhṛ (dhārayati)
having put down, gerund of ni-√dhā (nidadhāti)
having gone out, past passive participle of निस् -√गम् (निस्गच्छति) nis -√gam (nisgacchati)
decided, past passive participle of nis-√ni (nisnayati)
to strike down, slay; infinitive of ni-√han (nihanti)
lord, husband; irregular declension when used as husband not in a compound
wise, or as a noun: learned man (m)
flee (Goldmans comment: conjugate like an a-guṇa root from stem palāya)
distant, next [declined like the demonstrative pronouns, i.e., saḥ, tat, sā]
in another place, in the next world
a leaf-hut (used by ascetics in the forest)
see, used as the present active for √drś
bad, evil; as neuter noun: sin, wrong; as noun, bad man (m)
literally 'far shore;' with √gam: excel at, fully comprehend
protected, having been protected; past passive participle of √pāl, protect [Maurer lists √pālaya but CIS and Goldmans say √pāl]
afflicted, oppressed, pained, tormented; past passive participle of √pīḍ (pīḍayati)
again; punaḥ punaḥ: again and again
to put in front, appoint, enlist; infinitive of पुरस् -√कृ (पुरस्करोति) puras -√kṛ (puraskaroti)
previous, former [declined like the demonstrative pronouns, i.e., saḥ, tat, sā]
offspring, children, people of a kingdom or realm
having gotten, having acquired; gerund of pra-√āp (prāpnoti)
go back, return to (+accusative); (Maurer's Ch 4 entry lists the preverb prati as praty which reflects the sandhi of combining with ā)
answered, past passive participle of prati-√vac (prativakti)
an effort, ablative: with effort, with care
having stood forth, then having gone forth; past passive participle of  pra-√sthā
gotten, acquired, past passive participle of pra-√āp (prāpnoti)
out, outside; as postposed, with genitive
wise, or as a noun: wise person (f)
having become awake; past passive participle of √बुध् (बोधति)√budh (bodhati)
husband, lord (Goldmans note that even though it seems like a kinship term, it belongs to the class of agent nouns)
O, sir, (strictly bho:, the visarga being lost before voiced consonants)
of me, my; genitive singular of aham, I
great god,' applied to both Viṣṇu and Śiva
a great king, a supreme sovereign
negative used with an imperitave verb (example: 'mā śucaḥ,' says Kṛśṇa in BG18.66, 'don't fear')
me, accusative singular of aham, I
the Mālava country in west-central India
ritual offering to the gods (a Vedic sacrifice)
who, which, where;  used in relative clauses (the man who goes to the forest)
Used together in clauses like "where the sun never shines, I couldn't live there" - see Goldmans page 98
what (relative); also used (according to Goldmans, Chap 7) to introduce direct or indirect discourses, used with or without iti at the end.
whence, since, front the point that
where? Used in relative clauses, such as the house where Rāma lives.
as, just as, like, in the manner in which
if [picked up by tadā, then, in the main clause]
so long as, to the extent that (with tāvat)
harnesses, yokes, causative of: √yuj (yunikta), class 7 verb to join
blood [really a ppp of √raj (rajyati), class 4, be colored, be red; hence literally 'colored, red']
kingly rule, kingdom (with √kṛ: to rule, reign)
acquired, gained, received; past passive participle of √labh, to get/receive
speak, say, say to (+ accusative of person addressed)
or; placed after words in the same way ca is
know, recognize; ppp: vidita, infiitive: veditum or vettum, gerund: viditvā
smear all over; ppp: vilipta [the prefix 'vi' means 'here and there']
increased, grown; past passive participle of √vṛdh (vardhati)
killed, destroyed, 'caused to fall away,' past passive participle of causative of  वि -आ -√पद् (व्यापद्यते) vi -ā -√pad (vyāpadyate) a class 4 veb
literally 'causes to perish,' kills, destroys; causative of vi-ā-√pad, 'fall apart, disintegrate, perish'
layed down, having layed down [anyone please let me know if I'm using the wrong English 'lay']; gerund of √śī (śete)
vicinity; nearness, presence; locative samīpe + genitive = near
a heap, accumulation (Maurer says to pronounce as if written sañcaya)
all, each, every [declined like the demonstrative pronouns, i.e., saḥ, tat, sā]
with (used after instrumental to mark accompaniment)
to stand, be situated, stay, remain, be; usually attenuated to 'be.'
having caused to stand (gerund of the causitive of √sthā (tiṣṭhati), stand
love - use locative for object of love
used postposed to form a simple past tense
to remember; ppp: smṛta, gerund: smṛtvā/smṛtya; infinitive: smṛtum
oneself, by one's self, to one's self; used reflexively and applicable to all persons, i.e., himself, herself, yourself, etc.
literally 'self choice,' the name of a ceremony at which a princess chooses a husband, or has one chosen by contest
slay, kill, strike; ppp: hata, killed

a kind of goose; Maurer notes that Sanskrit literature talks about a kind of goose which was believed capable of separating pure milk from a misture of milk and water, and that this special ability is often alluded to.
